Summary: NC for 17.12: Mild. The snowpack will be stable and most widespread above 1100 metres around coire back walls and plateau. Low Haz.
SnowDistribution: Wet snowpack.  Cloudy on the tops with some bright spells between showers.  Winds approx 75 mph and above, serious and challenging conditions.
Comment: Rock and ice fall will be a potential hazard during the thaw conditions.
WeatherInfluences: Light rain will clear overnight, winds will be gale to storm force, South-Westerly in direction.  The freezing level will remain above the summits.
SnowStability: The snowpack will continue to thaw at all altitudes and remain well bonded and stable throughout.  The patchy snowpack will be most widespread around coire back walls and the plateau above 1100 metres.  Cornice remnants will be prone to collapse.   The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A mild day with rain at all levels on storm force West-South-Westerly winds.  The freezing level remained above the summits.
ObservedSnowStability: The snowpack is thawing at all altitudes and is generally well bonded and stable throughout.  The patchy snowpack is most widespread above 1100 metres around coire back walls and the plateau.  Cornices remnants remain prone to collapse.  The avalanche hazard is Low.

Summary: CM for 17.12 Insufficient snow cover to present any avalanche hazard.
SnowDistribution: No snow of any significance at any elevation.  Cloudy on the tops with brief brighter spells.  Winds 30 40 mph at Glen level.
Comment: Colder air is expect from the North-West during Monday evening. The freezing level will drop to around 600m-800m bringing some snow showers to the West.
WeatherInfluences: Storm force South-Westerly winds will continue, easing slightly after mid-day.  Heavy rain expected during daylight hours. Freezing level way above the summits.
SnowStability: Currently there is insufficient snow cover to present any avalanche hazard and avalanche reports will not be issued for this area. Go to the Blogs and Mountain info for area photos; area info will be provided by SAIS forecasters on a daily basis.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Storm force South-Westerly winds. Persistent rainfall across the forecast area. Freezing level well above the summits.
ObservedSnowStability: Currently there is insufficient snow cover to present any avalanche hazard and avalanche reports will not be issued for this area. Go to the Blogs and Mountain info for area photos; area info will be provided by SAIS forecasters on a daily basis.

Summary: SC for 17.12.23 Thawing snowpack. Generally stable. Potential for cornice remnant collapse. Hazard of ice and rock fall. Low Hazard.
SnowDistribution: Wet snow throughout.  Cloudy on the tops with some bright spells.  Winds 30-40 mph, progress difficult and tiring, blowing us over on occasions.
Comment: Cooler conditions arriving during Monday evening.
WeatherInfluences: Light rain overnight followed by a mainly dry, but overcast day. Strong South-Westerly winds throughout. Freezing level remaining well above all summits.
SnowStability: The remaining patchy snow will continue to thaw with diminishing cover. Thought soft and wet, the snow will be generally well bonded. Cornice remnants will be prone to collapse. Falling ice and rocks will present a hazard. The avalanche hazard will be Low.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: A mild day with light rain and strong winds. Plus 4.9 degrees centigrade at 930 metres at midday.
ObservedSnowStability: There has been significant snow loss in the past 24 hours. Patchy, wet snow is present above 850 metres on most aspects with deeper accumulations encountered in wind sheltered locations. The wet snow is generally well bonded and stable, with some minimal surface instability present in the steepest of locations. Small areas of partially collapsed cornicing are still present. The avalanche hazard is Low.

Comment: Currently there is insufficient snow cover to present any avalanche hazard and avalanche reports will not be issued for this area. Go to the Blogs and Mountain info for area photos and area info will be provided by SAIS forecasters on a daily basis
ObservedSnowStability: Currently there is insufficient snow cover to present any avalanche hazard and avalanche reports will not be issued for this area. Go to the Blogs and Mountain info for area photos and area info will be provided by SAIS forecasters on a daily basis

Summary: TOR for 17/12 Currently there is insufficient snow cover to present any avalanche hazard. Refer to blog for information.
SnowDistribution: Very mild, very wet and very windy.
Comment: Amber weather warning issued for heavy persistent rain over the Torridon forecast area for tomorrow.
WeatherInfluences: Expect heavy and persistent rain at all levels throughout the period with the freezing level well above the highest tops. Severe South-West gales overnight will progressively moderate slightly through the day.
SnowStability: Currently there is insufficient snow cover to present any avalanche hazard, therefore avalanche reports will not be issued for this area. Refer to the Torridon Blog and Mountain Information for details which will be provided by SAIS forecasters on a daily basis.
ObservedWeatherInfluences: Persistent heavy rain from mid morning onwards and very mild with the freezing level well above the tops. Gale and severe gale South-West wind at summit level.
ObservedSnowStability: Currently there is insufficient snow cover to present any avalanche hazard, therefore avalanche reports will not be issued for this area. Refer to the Torridon Blog and Mountain Information for details which will be provided by SAIS forecasters on a daily basis.
